Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A surprise, tie-breaking vote on a critical piece of legislation is happening in the next hour, and you must immediately contact the undecided representative.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, hands deep in soapy water, as my spouse hurriedly dusted the living room. The house buzzed with urgency—relatives would arrive in just a few hours, and every surface needed to shine. We’d promised each other to share the load, to make our home welcoming together. My phone vibrated on the counter, and I glanced at the screen: an alert from my activist group. The message was urgent—a surprise vote on the bill we’d fought for all year was happening in less than an hour. The outcome would hinge on one undecided representative, and I was supposed to call, to persuade, to be the voice for change. My spouse called out, asking for help with the guest room. I stared at the phone, heart pounding, torn between the promise I’d made at home and the cause that defined so much of who I am. The weight of both expectations pressed in, and I felt myself pulled in two, unable to ignore either call.
